participants.participant: Shelly J. Doran, Vice President-Investor Relations
David E. Simon, Chairman & Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Simon Property Group Earnings Conference Call. My name is Deanna and I'll be your operator for today. Later we will conduct a question-and-answer session. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the call over to your host for today, Miss Shelly Doran, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

Thank you. Welcome to Simon Property Group's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Please be aware that statements made during this call that are not historical may be deemed forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our filings at the Securities and Exchange Commission for a detailed discussion of these risks and uncertainties.

Acknowledging the fact that this call may be webcast for some time to come, we believe it's important to note that today's call includes time sensitive information that may be accurate only as of today's date, July 30, 2010.

During today's call we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC's Regulation G. Reconciliations of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included within the earnings release or the company's supplemental information package that was included in this morning's Form 8-K. This package is also available on the Simon Web site in the Investor section under Financial Information, Quarterly Supplemental Packages.
Participating in today's call will be David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer and Steve Sterrett, Chief Financial Officer.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Simon.
Okay. Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'll just give a few minutes of overview and then we'll open it up for some Q&A.

First, on the financial and operational front, we reported FFO of $1.38 per diluted share for the quarter, which was $0.04 above first-call consensus estimates, and which was also burdened by over $0.03 of non-recurring transaction expenses for the quarter.

In addition, we continue to lead our peer group in comparable property net operating income, generating 1.9% growth in the second quarter of 2010 and 2.3% for the six-month period. Drivers in this leading comparable NOI include revenue and rent growth, increases in occupancy, higher percentage rents as a result of increasing sales and our continued and effective cost control and management, as well as a reduction in bad debt compared to the previous period given the lower bankruptcies.

As of 6/30, comparable sales on a rolling 12-month basis were $474 per square foot as compared to $456 per square foot last year. Tenant reported sales 4.9% higher during the second quarter as compared to the second quarter of 2009. And on a year-to-date basis, recorded sales for the six months ended June 30 were 6.2% higher as compared to same period in 2009. As of 6/30, our occupancy was 93.1, 90 basis points higher than 3/31 and 80 basis points higher than one year ago. At June 30, the re-leasing spread for our trailing 12 months was $0.50 per square foot, or 1.2%. Leasing spreads have been impacted by a number of jewelry store closings, but I also want you to keep in mind that this is just base rent. We've had an increase in our CAM of at least that number if not more, and also we'd like you to keep in mind that our increase in occupancy of 90 basis points or 700,000 square feet includes some leasing in some tougher locations that we were able to accomplish in the second quarter.

Demand for space continues to improve. The ICSC convention was positive. Leasing activity has increased. And we fully executed 6.3 million square feet of new leases and renewals in the first six months of 2010 in malls and outlets as compared to 4.7 million square feet in the first six months of 2009.

Finally, in operational, and I just want to say the important point is that our year-to-date comparable NOI is up 2.3% with higher sales, higher occupancy and positive leasing spreads. Dispositions, let me move to that, in acquisition activity, as we disclosed in our earning release, we sold one asset in our GCI joint venture property Porta di Roma where we had a 19.6% interest, and our gain in that was $20 million. Of course, this is not included in FFO, and on July 15 we completed the previously announced sale of Simon Ivanhoe, our 50/50 joint venture – European joint venture with Ivanhoe Cambridge. We received 715 million euros, and Simon Property Group expects to gain – record a gain of approximately $280 million on the transaction in the third quarter.

We also entered into a JV with Unibail and Ivanhoe Cambridge to pursue the development of four new retail projects in France. We'll have a 25% interest in this venture and have the ability to determine on a project-by-project basis whether to retain our ownership interest.

On May 13, we acquired the 345,000 square foot outlet center from Prime, the Puerto Rico asset. In addition, on May 28, we increased our ownership interest of approximately 19% in Houston, which culminates in over a 50% interest in this terrific asset. The combined cost of these acquisitions was approximately $385 million and including the assumption of existing indebtedness.

Let me turn to the capital markets. In the first six months of the year, we paid off 700 million of senior unsecured notes. We've also unencumbered three malls, paying off approximately 800 million of mortgages in maturity. In July, we unencumbered two additional malls with $282 million of mortgages. The net result is we reduced our leverage by over $2 billion in the last seven months. The secured markets continue to improve, both on the life insurance market as well as with CMBS.

Year-to-date we've closed seven new loans totaling $900 million. 515 was from life companies, 330 million from CMBS placements and 55 million from bank loan. We've also locked rate in the third quarter of another $500 million of loans, 375 coming from insurance companies, 125 from CMBS originations. These three loans will have a weighted average of 5.3% and a term of ten years.

At the end of the quarter, we had 2.6 billion of cash on hand, including our share of JVs and the availability in our corporate credit facility, including the Simon Ivanhoe sale that occurred in July, which we used the partial proceeds to pay down our euro tranche of our revolver. We'll have 3.5 billion so a total capital availability of over $6.1 billion. Development activity, we are higher than our budget, yet in improving economic conditions. We originally budgeted around 100 million. We think we'll end up spending close to 200 million. We expect to have double-digit returns on this capital.

We're also excited to announce that we'll start the construction of Merrimack Premium Outlets in Merrimack, New Hampshire this fall with a projected opening in 2012. And we have two outlet centers undergoing significant expansions, the Houston Premium Outlets and Las Vegas Outlet centers.

Also we've done a very good job in our tactical projects redevelopment opportunities as we've reclaimed certain department store locations in big boxes. During the first six months of 2010, we opened 14 new anchors for big boxes, including Nordstrom, Best Buy, Bed Bath & Beyond, hhgregg. In addition, we have 15 additional stores under construction and scheduled to open in 2010 and again they include Forever 21, Whole Foods, Crate & Barrel and Target.

On the international front, there are two new premium outlet centers projected to open in 2010. Paju Premium in South Korea commenced construction in late March; that's in the northern part of Seoul. And Johor Premium Outlets is going to break ground in August. That will serve the Singaporean market. We're partnering with Genting Group, a well-known, well-respected company in Malaysia and throughout the world. And on completion in 2011, we will have 11 Premium Outlet Centers in Asia.

Now let me turn to Prime and then we're prepared to open up for questions. Our acquisition of Prime Retail is still being reviewed by the FTC and we are fully cooperating in that review. I wanted to give you a couple of updates on the specifics of the deal. As I mentioned, we closed on the Puerto Rican asset of the outlet, Prime's Outlet Center, and we're currently in the process of negotiating leases for all of the vacant space. And once those leases are executed we'll be 100% occupied.

We subsequently amended our agreement with Prime so that they will retain its St. Augustine Center as well as its Livermore and Grand Prairie development projects. And as we noted in our May conference call, U.S. anti-trust authorities have consistently recognized that the retail industry is highly competitive and fragmented. Retailers have many options to choose from when deciding where to sell their merchandise, including both a variety of brick and mortar locations and of course the internet, where sales growth has exploded in recent years.

We have received an overwhelming show of support from this deal from our retailer and it's – they recognize the highly competitive nature of this business, that our acquisition will provide a significant amount of new capital to a company currently in financial distress and put that capital to work to improve the operations of Prime assets and therefore improve the retailers' performance in those centers. We remain confident that we will close the remainder of the transaction, and as noted in our release, we have reaffirmed our 2010 guidance. And once precise timing of the closing of Prime transaction is known, we will provide an upgrade to our guidance upon that conclusion.
So finally, let me just say I am proud of our organization and the quarter that we produced, given all of the continuing uncertainty in the economic environment. And we're ready for questions.
And this first question will come from the line of Alexander Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.
Good morning.
Hey, how are you doing?
Doing well, happy it's Friday, although we have another week of earnings to go.
We don't.
Well then you can enjoy the weekend.
That's true.

Just going back to Prime, just want to get a little more color here. I mean, United and Continental only announced a deal a few months ago, EU's already approved that. What are your advisors and what is the FTC saying is just taking so long on this?

Alexander, I'd love to be able to comment further on it, but you'll just have to rely on the statements that I have made, and again we remain confident but I really don't have much to add beyond what I have mentioned.

Okay. And then switching to leasing, just want to get sort of an update on where you think TIs are going to end up this year. And then as we look at the re-leasing spreads over the next – or the rent roll over the next few years, if we think about $38 being the sort of market, and sort of $34 rent rolls, should we expect sort of 12% re-leasing spreads over the next few years?

Well look, I think a lot's been – we've read some of the analytic research today about the rent spreads, and I think we need to hearken back on a couple of things. One is last year was a tough, tough year, and as you know we did a number of things to help our retailers survive last year, and as those leases have been executed it has put, undeniably so, pressure on our leasing spreads. So what we're seeing in our results is exactly what we expected. And in fact I think the guidance that we gave to you early in this year actually thought – we though we would have comparable NOI down and we're actually performing much better than we anticipated.

I think as the market stabilizes we're convinced that we've got the ability to continue to generate positive leasing spreads that we have done historically as a public company for the last 17 years. So we are not immune to the economic environment that's occurred over the last 18 months. I'm proud of what we've done. The fact that we still have positive leasing spreads is a testament to the quality of our portfolio, a testament to our positive relationships with our tenants, and a testament to the organization. And I'd also say we leased, we increased our occupancy and in this market that's something to be proud of.

So bottom line, long winded, this is – as sales increases, certainly rents are related to the ability to deal with rent increases. Given that we've seen rents stabilize and sales are moving in the right direction, we feel good that we'll continue to generate positive leasing spreads.
And then the TI expectation for the year?
I have not shown any appreciable change. We're still basically seeing the same amount of TIs that we've had historically.
Okay. So like 75 or so for this year is fine?
I believe that's about where our run rate has been for the TIs.
Okay. Great. Thank you very much.
Thanks, Alex
And the next question will come from the line of Jeff Spector, Bank of America/Merrill Lynch.

Actually, it's Craig Schmidt here. Actually I wanted to talk on the, you had a really strong sequential pickup in occupancy, the 90 bps and I guess in part it sounds like you were able to lease some of the tougher locations you were saying. But as we look at the third and fourth quarter, should the sequential gains slow, or are there still more tough locations you think you can get leased up in the last half of the year?
Craig, this is Rick. We are still seeing a good flow of deals. Remains to be seen how much more we can sequentially increase on a 90 bp gain but we should be able to hold those gains year-over-year.

And certainly historically there is a pickup in occupancy as you go into the third and fourth quarter. So I would hope that we continue to do that. Obviously there was one reasonable-sized bankruptcy, Premier Salon. We don't think there's a lot more, but that's always the unknown. But we think that'll move in the right direction.
Okay. And do you have a sense of where the occupancy might actually end up end of the year?

I think – again, I think it'll be positive. I wouldn't want to pinpoint the number at this point. But we were looking – again, looking for flat occupancy compared to last year but I think we'll – in our guidance, but we'll be able to do better than that.
Okay. Thanks a lot.
Sure.
And the next question will come from the line Christine McElroy, UBS.

Hey. Good morning, guys. Just following up on some of your comments, I know how much you guys love questions on re-leasing spreads. I realize that the stores that are opening now are still reflective of some of the tougher leases that were signed last year or over the last couple of quarters. Can you give us a sense for what kind of spreads you're seeing on the small-shop leasing that you're doing today, and is that sort of giving you the confidence in your forward-looking comments?

Christine, it's Steve. And we are seeing an improvement, not only in deal flow, as David and Rick have talked about, but also in a strengthening of the quality of the deals. So I do think the trends are positive. I also think one of the things to think about, and I don't know if other people have talked about it on their calls, but one of the things that's impacting spreads is we have had a disproportionate amount of jewelry store closings, which are high rent payers.

David mentioned it in his call. But to the extent that that has run its course, that drag on our spreads will cease to be there. And because the rest of the activity is getting better, you should see a naturally pickup in the spreads.

Okay. And then Steve, just following up on Prime. Thinking about the timing, can you remind us, what was expected accretion from the Prime deal in your current guidance range and how much did it contribute?

Well, again, this is David. Let me, let me, I'll take the Prime questions if I could. I think the important point at this point is we're going to update our guidance once we know the precise timing of the closing of the transaction. The fact that when we gave guidance originally, we had Prime in it from March 31. Now we have not backed off our guidance, even though we have not had Prime since March 31, and we have reaffirmed our guidance and we will upgrade it and update it once we know the precise timing. So beyond that, Christine, I can't really shed any more light on it other than again, we had budgeted that. We told the world that, that, that was in our guidance from the end of the – or the very – April 1 essentially, in the second quarter. So we produced the results. We beat our own internal budget even though we had Prime in it for the whole quarter.

Okay. Rick, you've talked in the past about things looking up for the department stores: performances better, balance sheets are better. But they're still sort of working on making their existing product more productive. Could that include more department-store closings or maybe even downsizings on the horizon and would you be willing to modify REAs and other agreements to allow certain underperforming anchors to maybe sublease a portion of their box?

Well, that covers a lot of ground. First, Dave and I literally last week were with three of our major department store companies and none of them were talking about store closings. In fact, the emphasis now is looking for new opportunities and primarily in our existing product. So we expect that to be the trend rather than store closings.

Secondly, in terms of the modification of subleases, we are in – we are always trying to make our properties better. I think, as David has pointed out in past calls, that we've been very active with replacing underperforming anchors with better anchors and we're going to continue to do that. So if there are things that we can do working with existing department stores that we believe will make the property stronger, we're going to be open to have that conversation.

And Christine, this is David. Let me just say, as the – and again, I think we are still in an uncertain economic macro environment. But one of the things – we have a, I'd say roughly 20 potential transformational redevelopments that we've been working on. We essentially put them on hold, obviously last year, and we have reinvigorated the company to pursue those.

And I think they're very exciting. It'll add a lot of opportunity for our company and we're going to accelerate that process. And then you know they go from South Hills in Pittsburgh to Plaza Carolina in Puerto Rico to La Plaza in McAllen, Texas, Dayland, Phleman Nanuet, Roosevelt Field, Walt Whitman. So there's a lot that we're excited about internally that we've kind of said let's get started on.
Great, thanks so much.
Thanks.
Our next question will come from the line of David Harris, Gleacher and Company.
Hey, good morning, guys.
How are you?
Good, I'm fine, thank you. I have two quick questions for you. One is upon a detail, and then another big picture question for you, David.
You want me to do the detail?
Why not? Have a go. Real estate taxes were down notably in the quarter. Is that just a sort of timing issue or are you doing something wonderful to keep your tax liabilities down?

I think it is more of the latter, but I wouldn't categorize it as wonderful. We have an ongoing, sophisticated process to make sure we believe we are being fairly assessed reflecting the value of the properties, and that's – there's a whole group of people that are focused on that and we're yielding some results by engaging with the taxing authorities on the real estate taxes.
So the second quarter number is a reasonable run rate, Rick?
I believe it is.
Okay. Terrific.

There is David. Here's my detail response. There are – at times, there are recoveries – it's a little bit lumpy, because at some point you get recoveries and obviously if we do have those – I don't know on the top of my head if we had that in the – we had some recoveries in the second quarter. So sometimes it's a little bit lumpy because you do get recoveries that you're allowed to offset against the expenses and obviously, though Rick's point is right on, I mean we are extremely focused that our properties are appropriately assessed.

Okay. Stay there, I've got you for the big question. Is it – I think about your company, which has been public, what, for 16, 17 years? We've been through two recessions now. Can you demonstrate that your management and ownership of the underlying property performance is demonstrably better than the market?

And if so, how do you use that in your discussions with – in terms of forming potential joint ventures or potentially talking to pension funds about transfer of assets that have perhaps underperformed under direct ownership and that could do so much better under your ownership?

Well that sounds like I need a whitepaper to respond. But look, I think our results over the years have clearly spoken for themselves. We've transformed properties. We've upgraded our portfolio. We've produced terrific operating results in all sorts of different environments. We've made appropriate strategic decisions like the Outlet business and the like.

From an operating point of view, David, we get solicited all the time to be partners with institutional investors. There's not a deal that we couldn't have done with an institutional investor, and I think they look and welcome our ability to partner with us. And I'm sure we could probably back all these statements up with numbers if you give us some time, and maybe that's a good assignment for us, but there's no question in my mind that over the years our performance and our results have certainly indicated that we're better than just what the general economic environment could produce. I don't know if you guys want to add anything to it.

My thinking is along those lines, David, that clearly your focus has been, from the beginning of the year; let's look at the opportunities in the U.S. And clearly your pursuit of general growth=> clearly your pursuit of General Growth ended when it did. And I'm thinking where does Simon go in terms of potentially buying assets in what is obviously – there aren't that many assets to buy in the marketplace, and some of those have been held for a long time, but probably with people that have perhaps underperformed in the performance of those assets relative to what you could do. Is there a line of conversation you can have with those folks and say, look over an extended period of time we could do much better with this asset. I'm not talking about FFO or earnings per share from the corporate level; I'm talking about underlying property performance.

Well look, I think that the evidence of our ability to do that is in a couple of cases. I mean first of all, if you look at what we built in Asia on the Outlet side, we basically exported our talent there, and we're going to have a portfolio of 11 outlet centers that are producing close to $1,000 a foot in sales. So also, even though we just recently sold our properties in – the two in Poland and the five in France – the fact of the matter is we built them, we developed them, we leased them, and we brought an institutional quality product to those marketplaces with our guidance and our leasing expertise and the like. So I think there's plenty of evidence of our ability to export our know-how.

Now you don't want to do it in a way that suggests hubris because there's been plenty – certainly plenty of developers that have tried to do that and have not been able to produce the results that are necessary to be profitable overseas. I'd also point out that a number of our customer or retail tenants have been successful in exporting their brands, so even though we have sold seven assets in Europe, the fact of the matter is we are not foreclosing the opportunity to grow our company globally. I think we've been successful in our efforts thus far there, and I think the ability to demonstrate that is readily apparent.
Is one way to summarize what you're saying is that you see limited opportunities to buy domestically?

I didn't say that, and I don't necessarily believe that. Look, you can say that in a point in time, but I do think circumstances change and the environment that exists today in my opinion is not necessarily going to be the environment that exists tomorrow or the next day, and you've got to be in a position to deal with that.
Okay. I'll let you answer the next detail question. Thank you.
And the next question will come from the line of Jay Habermann, Goldman Sachs.

Hey, good morning. You know, David, you're still sitting on a pretty strong balance sheet with as you mentioned lots of cash in current liquidity. I'm just wondering, of the various options you have today, how you would rank either development, acquisitions or even looking at further paying down debt?

Well we're going to continue to de-lever if there's not the acquisition opportunities to pursue. But like I said, Jay, is that I do think I've given Rick and the team the green light to go reenergize our redevelopment program. And again, we have 15, 20 really transformational assets that I think are going to require meaningful capital and produce wonderful results. So there's plenty to do. Obviously we're working on some interesting opportunities today but, look, our focus clearly has been to – we'll pursue General Growth; we weren't successful there. I'll leave that for you to judge that whole process. But our focus obviously has been on Prime and we've been working very hard to get that transaction closed. And so I think once we can get some of that done, then I think there'll be plenty of opportunities for this company.

Fair enough. And just going back to leasing spreads and I guess sales, I mean the trend has clearly been positive this year in terms of sales productivity. I guess when do you start to see that translate into some pickup and in asking rents, and I guess just balancing that against retailers that continue to be pretty sensitive to occupancy costs?

Well, I think it's – you know look, we're still, we're in a recovery mode. The mood is much better. I mentioned we increased our occupancy but we're not, it's not in the period that we were in, in the '06, '07 period. So I think that's still, Jay, going to still take some time to max out on lease spreads. But look, the mood's better, the demand is better and sales are increasing. So there's a lag in all of that but we feel we'll get back to kind of the spreads that we would like to see going forward.
Thanks, David.
It may take a little more time but it's moving in that direction. Thanks, Jay.
And the next question will come from the line of Quentin Velleley with Citi. Please proceed.

Good morning. There's been a bit of chat about acquisitions again. I'm just curious whether, given the demand for mall assets at the moment, is there some kind of opportunity to start sort of recycling capital and potentially looking at selling some of your middle-market malls?

I think at some point, we still, there is still a – we like our middle-market malls that dominate a good trade area because they have shown, historically, growth. The stuff that we'd like to sell really is what I'll call the gum on the shoe. That market is still slow to develop, Quentin, so hopefully maybe that comes along. There's not that many that have been earmarked for that, but to the extent that, that market starts to generate, we'll move forward.

Now we do have certain non-strategic assets on the market that have some redevelopment opportunity, so I think – and they're getting more and more interest. So I think we've demonstrated – we've probably sold 50 assets over the years. We certainly have recycled some of the European capital. So I think we've shown a pretty good discipline that we're prepared to recycle capital through asset sales.

Okay. I think I saw that your joint venture partner in the Copley one portfolio is potentially selling their stake. Is that something that you would have any interest in, and if so, is there a right of first offer or anything that you have on that?

Well there are contractual restrictions, Quentin. It's not appropriate to get into that, but we're working with our partner in a way – it's been a very good investment. It's been a very good partnership and obviously institutional investors to some extent need to recycle capital. So there's a lot of different ways that can go, but it's been a good transaction for all of the folks involved and we'd expect that to continue, whether they stay a partner or whether they exit.

Okay. And maybe one for Steve. I just noticed in the second quarter that interest and dividend income jumped by quite a lot. Just wondering why that was and whether that's likely to run into the third quarter.

Well a couple of things, Quentin. One – and I don't know if you're comparing it to last year or to the first quarter – but Liberty, or now Capital and Counties and Capital Shopping Centres does pay a semi-annual dividend. That came in the second quarter, so if you were comparing it to the first quarter, that would be part of the explanation. And we have seen rates on our short term invested cash get marginally better so we're investing the cash at a little bit higher rates than we've seen. Those would be the two major reasons.

Okay. And just the other one for the model, in terms of transactions costs, I know you closed the Simon Ivanhoe sale to Unibail on the 15th of July. Are there going to be any costs that come in, in the third quarter?

It's, yeah, it's likely, given that obviously some of the transaction costs associated with Prime will continue in parts of the third quarter, so yes. Hard to pinpoint that number down right now. As you know there – you have the accounting change. Normally that would capitalized, but Quentin, it will continue, but again it's hard to pinpoint that number at this point.

Got you. And then just lastly, Liz Claiborne in the Chelsea outlets, they have obviously announced that they'll be closing some of their outlets. Just wondering if you've had any discussions with them yet and what your exposure is.

Well we have had ongoing discussions with them. We've got 16 outlets that are exclusively Liz and that's about a 190,000 square feet. We've got another 12 outlets that are hybrid where there is a Liz component along with other brands from Liz Claiborne like Lucky, Kate Spade or Juicy Couture. That's about another 46,000 feet. We list our top tenants and they're not in our top ten and so their rental contribution to us is substantially below 1% of our minimum rent, and we're going to approach this like we approach everything else. They have their business objectives, we have ours, and we're going to work with them to hopefully come up with a mutually acceptable conclusion.
And Rick, do you think that those leases are currently paying rent at market or are they below what you'd expect market rents to be?
We think that there could be opportunity for both of us if we can come up with a thing that allows them to satisfy their objectives and us ours.
Okay. All right, thank you.
Thank, Quentin.
Our next question will come from the line of Paul Morgan, Morgan Stanley
Hi, good morning.
Hi, Paul.

The thinking about the short term leases that you are signing, I know you didn't do maybe quite as many as some of the peers, but – over the past couple of years. And what's your experience then as those have started to expire? And are tenants more interested in doing longer term renewals now or are you still kind of rolling over a year at a time?

It's a combination of both. I mean again, a lot of it is retailer-specific, but there is still a level of uncertainty out there. And so – and again, a lot of it's tactical on our side too, in terms of what we're trying to accomplish with the properties. So I'd say it's marginally better, marginally probably the ability to get a little longer-term lease, but it's not dramatically different than the beginning of the year, Paul.

Okay. And then going to the redevelopments that you mentioned, you characterized those as transformational. I mean a few years ago, transformational often included some mixed-use component or opening it up partially. Are these more conservative do you think or is it the same type of project that you were thinking of doing four years ago?

I mean the good news about our mixed-use stuff, it's been highly, highly successful, like Domain in the residential market has been terrific, and so we haven't had net-net mixed-use elements that we've brought in. The Westin Hotel there has been very well received. So I think we've done a pretty good job in bringing that.

But to us, the number one priority in any retail development is make it a better retail project. And I think generally speaking, though there may be certain elements, maybe there's a hotel opportunity here or there or a residential opportunity here or there, the primary focus is on the retail aspect of it. And yeah, I would say generally the scope may have been narrowed to some extent, so we're trying to figure out how to do it a little bit less grandiose, but not wildly different.
And the return hurdles, now that we're seeing it again?

I think the return hurdles, given the cost of construction and the demand out there for construction jobs, is actually going to be pretty good, pretty consistent. Otherwise, look, at the end of the day if it's not, we go on to the next deal.

Okay. And then just lastly, Rick, you said TIs were kind of no real change there, but at least in your supplemental what you report is about 75 million year to date, which is quite a bit higher than past years' run rates, and I was just wondering maybe if some of this is just catch up from having such a low year last year or whether really it is certain economics of the deal environment right now, or what. But it is higher than what you've reported at least over the past few years.

Paul, this is Steve. I think Rick's comment was more to the point that on a deal-by-deal basis we never – per square foot we haven't really seen any change in the bid and the ask on the TI side. Clearly, we've had more leasing volume this year. You know our leasing volume is up about a million and a half square feet year over year, and that's driving the size of the number, but the composition of the deals and what deals get TAs and how much and all that really hasn't changed.
Okay. Great. Thanks.
Thank you.
The next question will come from the line of Michael Gorman, Cowen & Company.

Thank you. Good morning, guys. If I could just follow up on that TI question for a second. Can you just walk through in this environment how you think about the allocation of TAs and the potential return on those as you sit down with tenants, especially given the strong position on your balance sheet and the cash that you have to invest? So the trade off between potentially earning a higher rent from a tenant versus having to commit the capital?

Well, look, I don't think you want to – I don't know, maybe I'm misunderstanding the question, but I don't think you want to get to the point where you're giving more TA and buying up rent. I think that creates an unholy alliance. And frankly the retailers, you know, from their standpoint they're in a good capital position as well. So, you know, they want to pay market rents. Market rents are determined by sales productivity, so I think that the traditional way that we've done leasing is – still holds.

We never been – as a company, we've always been reluctant to do some of the new fancy under-capitalized retailers that have a history, not to say that we've been perfect in this area, but we certainly have been, I think at least, from what I see externally and internally, we've always been relatively conservative in terms of putting capital at risk for tenants that are under-capitalized. But I'd say generally if you have a healthy retailer, you know, you just don't get in that scenario. It's not a win-win for either side.
Got you.

And the only think I would add is we, when we're doing our lease approvals, we analyze each lease based on net rent that takes into account the allowance and we also have a very stringent credit process as our leasing agents will attest. So both of those things tend to limit the allowance in relation to rent.

Got you. And David, if I could turn for a second to the outlet business, obviously with Prime going on there's been a lot of discussion about consolidation in the space. But looking at if from another perspective, you guys have had great success with that property type since 2004. How do you think about the potential risk as the regional mall property type tightens up, that you see more entrance into the outlet center space, more competition for land, more competition for deals? And potentially lower return hurdles going forward?

Well, look. I, I do think you've put on a – you do make an excellent point. Forget consolidation. There are a number of new entrants in the outlet sector. Obviously, we all saw the Taubman announcement. We think there are other mall companies out there that are looking for it. And the product is in favor, and we expect to see more and more developments. Tanger has announced a number of sites. And they have a large pipeline.

So it is competitive and it will remain really competitive, if not more competitive, given the new entrants and the possibilities. So – I mean that's a fact of life. We're – retail real estate is wildly competitive. It's competitive on a local basis all the time. And so we'll just have to – we'll have to deal with it. It doesn't force us to do bad developments at low returns. But obviously there's going to be a number of new opportunities out there for the retailers to assess and participate in.

Great. And then just one last one, maybe for Rick. Can you just talk for a little bit about the performance of maybe what you would call non-traditional anchors as they've come onto your malls? Maybe some of the newer leases, it's too soon to tell. But some of the other atypical anchors, how they've been performing, and maybe even more so, how the wings that they're on have been performing, as well.

Well, you look in the, in the 8-K. We are accelerating that activity. And our approach is there's nothing sacred about our hundred acres. And we want to bring as much quality retailing as we can to our properties. And they have helped drive traffic. They have helped to create additional internal traffic, and to the extent that they are adding uses that are not otherwise available in the property, it's all very positive. So it's something that we have been very good at for a long time, and we're going to continue to do it because we think it adds an additional dimension to our properties.
Okay. Great. Thanks.
And the question will come from the line of Jeffrey Donnelly, Wells Fargo.

Good morning, guys. David, I think you guys were fairly successful winding down developments and other activities ahead of this most recent downturn. And has the specter of a slowing economy that we continue to hear about lead you to think differently about the tactics that you're employing now on leasing, or leverage or capital allocation?

Well certainly, capital allocation and not getting over your skis, there's no question about it. And I'd say to you that the re-development – I'll call it the transformational properties that we'd like to kick-start – is all really led by retail demand. So it's not an issue that we're forcing. I think, if anything, we don't want to force the issue on redevelopment or new development. We want the demand to be there. And if you can – if the demand is there today, in a still-uncertain environment, that – obviously these centers have been around a long time and have proven to withstand a lot of different cycles. And it's infill core real estate. So the answer is, we think we can make some of this work.

And again, not all of it will work. But there's no question about – the last cycle here has taught us a lot, told us that we had to have access to a lot of different forms of capital. It told us to – it taught us never to over-promise, to have good relationships with our shareholders and our institutional partners. And I think we've always been – we've done a lot of M&A stuff over the years but we've always financed it conservatively, and certainly as that develops we certainly understand that going forward.

And since you mentioned the redevelopment and development, on New England do you think the Merrimack property that you're looking at starting will pencil to the 12 to 14% yields you traditionally get out of the ground-up development and outlets? And how do you underwrite cannibalizing the other properties, like such as the Kittery or Wrentham outlets?

Well we think it's its own separate market. And, look, I think you bring up a good point. The numbers that we're pro forma-ing now are less rents than we would have thought two years ago. Because I think we have to be more conservative in underwriting it, but we still see it as an 11% return on cost, and yeah it's lower than what it was, but it's...
But we also carry the land for three years.
Yeah. And I think Steve's right. The land's been there for a while and like I said, the demand is there. If the demand weren't there, we wouldn't force the issue.

And just one last question if I could I guess revisit with Quentin's line of questioning on the New England assets. Is it fair to say, though, that your chance – that there's a chance that you could increase your ownership stake in some of your New England assets? And I guess as a follow up, can you give us a little color on the Atrium? Do you think that property ceases to be a mall in the future?

Well, there is a possibility we could increase or ownership in our Mayflower joint venture, so we can plan a lot of different ways but that's certainly a possibility. Atrium, in our opinion, probably needs to be redeveloped and there's a great opportunity in doing that. We think we just have other better uses of our energy in terms of what we're trying to accomplish so that's why us and our partners have decided to put that on the market. Obviously, we're price-sensitive in terms of it is very good real estate, but ultimately it's less of a retail development and it's more of an alternative use, which is just – not that we couldn't do it, but it's just not our core competency. We'd rather focus on retail.
Great. Thanks, guys.
Thanks.
And the next question will come from the line of Nathan Isbee, Stifel Nicolaus.
Hi, good morning.
Hey.
Hey.

A few quick questions. Just going back to the same store NOI. The original guidance was one to 1.5% positive for the total portfolio. You're tracking 2, 3 through the first six months. Where would you peg that now for the full year?
Well can I just say, Nate, before I answer, I just want to say I saw Dave is retiring. I want, obviously, everybody from our side wish him well. He's been a – I'm going to miss his barbs.
He gave me a long lesson before he left on how to do it.

I get that sense, some of that may have rubbed off, but hopefully we can handle it. But he's been, obviously, a very well thought of analyst and we just want to pass on our best wishes to Dave, and we will miss his barbs. But I'm sure you'll pick up on that front.
I'll do my best.
In any event, your question on comp NOI; look, there's still uncertainty with it but if we can maintain that I will be very, very pleased given where we originally projected.
So you're not willing to change that yet?
I'm not willing to change it at this point.
Okay.

Look, I do think that the fact that we've re-affirmed our guidance, given what I've described about Prime, indicates to you that you know, look we're doing – I'm pleased with how we're performing at this point.

Okay, and as you – moving to Prime for a minute, in the papers here a few weeks ago there was a little blurb about Prime giving notice to the State of Maryland by September 5th they plan to dial back their home office significantly. Is there anything to read into that date?
No, other than what I've described to you, you know, there's nothing more that I can add.

Okay, and then just going back to the outlets in general, you had mentioned Tanger's pipeline. They've mentioned looking at 17 sites currently in addition to three that are more live. When you look at the landscape over the last 15 to 20 years there's been a net decline in outlet centers in the U.S. How much can this country – how many more centers can this country absorb in your mind as you look at it?

Look the answer is we're going to find out. I do think there's going to be a number of centers built, so you know, we'll find out. But you know, there are a number of centers planned. There is very competent developers that are going to do that. Obviously Tanger's successful in their developments, Taubman's a very good developer, they'll be very successful. There's a number of potential conversions that are taking place, like what Vornado did with Bergen. Even though I'd really like to know his returns, he won't tell me, but – no, I'm kidding. I think he's done a very good job on Bergen Town Center. There's a number of malls that are looking to merge and sell. It's clear that consumer wants value and it's clear that there's going to be a lot more new and re-developed centers focused on value for the benefit of the consumers and for the benefit of the retailers.

And whether we'll do too much or not remains to be seen. I think our industry always pushes the envelope. I would think if you saw some of the developments that occurred and that have stopped over the years, over the last couple years, you could see that we've pushed the envelope. I would not be surprised if we didn't push the envelope here but there's a lot of new opportunities out there and they're being pursued by very competent developers, both on new and redeveloped formats for the outlet sector.
How many sites is Simon/Chelsea looking at today?

Our focus obviously has just been on Prime, but besides Merrimack we probably have two or three in the U.S. that we're looking at. And I will tell you this, though: we're very focused on our Asian outlets, Nate. We've been very successful there. We're very excited about a Singapore market, Malaysia. We're very excited about what's going on in Korea and Japan. Despite all the macro stuff that our centers are doing, performing very well there. So our ability and brand might grow reasonably well in the outlet side in the U.S. -- outside the U.S. And I will mention – Rick's pointing to me, I do think it's important to note that we're also expanding a few of our outlet centers here in the U.S, and that will also happen, I think, in our industry.
All right. Thanks.
Thanks, Nate.
And the next question will come from the line of Carol Kemple, Hilliard Lyons.
Good morning.
How are you doing?
Good. David, earlier in the call I think you said something that Prime was going to retain interest in three of their centers?
That's correct.
What is the reason for that? Is that they feel better capital-wise? Or is that something the FTC is wanting them to do?
I really can't add more, Carol, than I've already told you.
Okay. Can you add or can you say if it's going to change the purchase price?

There has been a modification to the transaction, and you know, I can say that the capital that Prime would receive, as part of the transaction will allow Prime to go develop, and I guess I should have mentioned this in Nate's call or question. It will allow them to go develop their deal in Livermore and Grand Prairie, and that's their intention to do so.
Okay. In the quarter, were the leasing spreads positive, both the malls and the outlet centers? Or just the outlet centers?

We put those statistics together. Obviously the malls have a significant impact on the results, given that they're in the 75, 80% range of our domestic NOI in that number. But we don't break that out now, Carol.
Okay. I knew you didn't break it out percentage, but I didn't know if you could comment in general. Okay. Thank you.
Thank you.
And the next question will come from the line of Ben Yang, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.

Yeah, hi. Good morning. I'm just curious how much of the occupancy gain was attributable to you converting your month-to-month tenants into longer term deals, because it looks like you have about 200 fewer temp tenants compared to last quarter. I mean, did you just convert up to this 900,000 square feet into longer term deals? Or did these guys just end up closing their stores?

Interestingly, for the most part, we have been transitioning to more national tenants as opposed to the month-to-month. And a lot of times, the month-to-month is because we don't want to go longer term because we want to have a room split. We want to combine rooms for a different tenant that will pay more rent. So this was not really a process of a lot of month-to-month conversions.

Hey, Ben, this is Steve. I would just add one more thing. Rick and David talked a lot on our calls over the last four or five quarters about consciously slowing down the leasing activity because of the difficulty in the environment, so that month-to-month number was, to some degree, the result of a lease expiring where we chose, and the tenant chose, not to, a year ago or nine months ago, enter into a permanent deal. We are now, if you will, addressing that given the recovery in the U.S.
And Steve's right. I mean I don't know what the exact number is, but certainly some of those month-to-months have gone to longer-term leases.
That sounds like most of them ended up just closing their stores and maybe just...
I mean there's...
Is that fair?
Yeah. We suffered a lot of store closings, that's for sure.
Okay. And then you mentioned some actually converting to permanent leases. When you do make those conversions, does that number show up in your re-leasing spread?
It does. If a temporary tenant converts to a permanent deal, then we treat it as a new lease, that's correct.
Okay. So this – okay, great. Thank you.
Thanks, Ben.
And the next question will come from the line of Michael Mueller, JPMorgan.

Yeah, hi. A few quick ones here. On the development JVs in France, can you give us a sense as to how much Simon capital could potentially go into that? And over what timeframe it will begin to play out?

We're only laughing because the drilling for answers is a long, frustrating process. Mike, we don't – it's right now to pursue the development is not going to be a lot of money for us. And as an example the Toulouse development itself could be north of a couple hundred million euros. But again it's – the timing and the approvals is really uncertain, so I would hate to venture, but for us to keep our optionality alive is – will be not a very big number.
Okay. So it's longer term stuff and...

Yeah. It is. I mean the biggest one of which is on the potential front burner is the development in Toulouse that all of us are – Unibail, us, as well as Ivanhoe Cambridge are excited about pursuing, but again that needs to go a through a certain process.
Okay.
Don't ask me to explain it.

No problem. And few quick ones for Steve. Steve, going back to the TI question, I previously had down, I was looking through notes in 2010 maybe 75 million on the low end, 100 million on the high end. I mean what's the full year expectation now for TIs?

Michael, I mean we've had an increase in velocity, so I wouldn't necessarily expect it to be 2x of what it was through the first six months, but I think it'll clearly be at that $100 million or a little bit more range.
Okay.
And I think that's just an increase in the leasing velocity.

Okay. And then when we look at debt maturities over the next year or so, a lot less bonds maturing in 2011 than we saw in '10 and '09. How should we think or you thinking differently about what a more normalized cash position is?

Well that's a very good question. The answer is yeah. Eventually we're going to have kind of a normalized number. I can't – it would be hard for me to pinpoint exactly today what that is, as we still try to sort through the uncertain economic environment. But today we're over capitalized, not wildly over capitalized but we've reduced our debt by $2 billion. We're generating cash flow – positive cash flow. Our dividend is obviously very safe and sound. So at the end of day we want to kind of just still be a little more thoughtful, a little more cautious as to where the economic environment comes out. Obviously there's the deflation specter out there. There's a lot to weigh into that, that we've got to continue to be just really extra conservative in our thought process for the time being.
Okay. That should be it. Thanks.
Thanks.
And the next question will come from the line of David Wigginton, Macquarie.

Thank you. Good afternoon, guys. Most of my questions have been answered. Just had a couple of quick follow ups on lease term fees in the quarter. It kind of spiked up in the quarter. I wasn't sure if that was a result of the jewelry store closings you had mentioned or if there was something else that had played into that.

There was a couple of those and then other – we don't like to name the tenants – but there were a couple of deals that were store closings that were negotiated, and again that's not in our comparable NOI numbers, but I'd just prefer not to name the tenants. There was one aspect of a jewelry retailer that exited the business, so that did spike up because of that.

Okay. So then just staying with the jewelers, where would you say we are in the shakeout process among operators at this point of the cycle or what not? Have we worked our way through the majority of jewelers that need to just shut down and go out of business, or are there more to come?

I would think that a lot has taken place, so I think we're past for a lot of that, but there's still probably excess capacity in the jewelry retail space overall. So it's like the restaurants. In a sense, the restaurants get a demand of, I don't know; close 1% of the restaurant space in America. So I still think there's probably a little bit more to go, but I would say we've gone through a lot of it.

I recognize the split among store closings is probably pretty evenly across your portfolio, but have you noticed any excessive closings say in one segment of your portfolio versus another, maybe like at the higher end or lower end?
Not really. I mean I think the regional economies have a lot of impact, not on – not necessarily the – a particular property size.

Okay. And then just last question, and this was touched on a little bit earlier, but with respect to sales increases leading to rent increases, historically what has been the timeline that you've observed in your portfolio, if anything? Is it different from what you would expect to see in general in a regular mall portfolio? And do you feel like you are able to capture pricing power quicker than maybe most mall operators?

No. I think we're no different than – there's a lag, and there's also a certain level of certainty that the retailer wants as they see their sales increase. I mean they don't – if they have a good quarter it doesn't necessarily mean – you know, their open to buys might increase but they're still going to be pretty conservative on the rent to sales ratio. So there's a lag and it's a macro-impact and we're no better than anybody else in that category in terms of being able to accelerate that gap.
Okay. I mean, is it just a matter of them seeing several quarters, consecutive quarters of sales increases that gets them going?

I think it's also very specific on the retailer and the position that they're in and what they're trying to do. Are they trying to gain market share? Are they trying to penetrate a regional market further? So there's a lot that goes into it, but generally the retailers are taking a reasonably conservative stance and rightfully so, just like we are in a lot of respects.
Okay. Thank you.
Thanks.
And we have a question from the line of Rich Moore, RBC Capital Markets.

Hello, guys. On the dividend, David, where do you guys stand on that? It seems to me that you're at some sort of a minimum payout ratio at this point and you've got to raise the dividend. Does that sound right?
You're warm.
So not yet, but getting there.

You're warm. Yeah, look. I think we're going to have to assess – obviously, our taxable income is going to be affected by the Simon Ivanhoe sale, so we have to factor that in and obviously we're going to spend the next four or five months doing that, but in addition to that, Rich, I think as we look at it, '11, our taxable income, there's a lot of stuff that is going on with us in terms of our taxable income. We had the share issuance, so we had more shares outstanding. We had the taxable write-off associated with the bond premium that we paid. Assuming all of that kind of just normalized – we spent this year normalizing all of that, then I look at '11 and again, it's – obviously we're projecting an economic environment, but '11, but let's assume it's consistent with what we have, I mean we are, I would venture to say, at the bare, bare minimum of what we need to pay given where we are today. So that will definitely have to be addressed on the more permanent basis in '11, as a lot of the extraordinary events of the last year have played themselves out.

Okay. Very good. Thank you. And then, Steve, on the straight line ran item, that seemed to jump pretty high in the quarter. Is there anything special in there? And then does it go back down from here?
Nothing really special, Rich. And again, we talked about leasing the lock, and it being higher. That tends to be driven by the square footage of deals you're doing.

Okay. Got you. And then same kind of thing on the preferred dividends for IA. That was actually negative. I assume that's some sort of accounting treatment for the retirement of the IA, is that right?
Yeah. It's just a clean up and a true up for the redemption of the IA that we did in the first quarter.
Okay, great. And then on the recoveries, the recovery ratio, that was also a bit higher than usual. Is that going to continue, you think?

Well, I mean – listen, we're an environment now, Rich, where we're 80% converted to fixed TM. Most of those have contractual annual increases in the recovery. So to the extent that we're able to manage our expenses at a rate below that, you should see the recovery continuing to get better.
Okay, excellent. And then the last thing, Rick, the list of retailers that are hot today, or that are getting hotter in the second quarter, have you got that?

Well, we always hesitate to do that because everybody else then starts calling them. But we are doing deals in '10. PF Fiero was rolling out, Sperry and Stride Rite from Collective Brand, Michael Kors, Rue 21, Francesca. We're doing Microsoft deals. We're doing Pandora deals, Lego, Crazy 8, with Gymboree and as David – Forever 21. As David has alluded to, there is a little bit higher velocity and an interest and we're hopefully taking advantage of that.
And, and on the box side, Rich, look, Target, Kohl's, I mean they're looking for mall opportunities. So that bodes well for us as well.
Okay, excellent. Great. I knew you had that list. Thank you, guys.
Thanks for asking.
We have a question from the line of Ian Weissman, ISI.

Yes. Just a housekeeping question for Steve. The $13 million of transaction costs that you had this quarter, is that related to Prime? And if so, can we expect similar expenses for the balance of the year?
No. It's not just Prime, Ian. It's a combination of all – multiple transactions that we were working on, some of which will occur, some of which didn't occur.

I mean, I said, Ian, earlier that we'll continue to have Prime expenses in the third quarter but that's a higher run rate, and then obviously upon that transaction closing as we expect that, that number ought to obviously come down.
Okay. All right. Thank you very much.
Okay. Thank you.
Thank you.
And this concludes the question-and-answer portion of today's call. I'd like to turn the call back to Mr. David Simon for closing remarks.
Okay. Thank you, everybody, for participating. We look forward to talking to you in the future. Take care.
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's conference. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect and have a great day.
